title: You've got this!
detailedDescription:
Stepping back into the world of education might seem daunting, but remember, every great journey begins with a single step—and you're already on your way. This plan isn't just a guide; it's a reflection of your ambition, your dreams, and your future.

Here's what you're unlocking:

  • Clarity and Confidence: No more second-guessing. Every piece of advice here is tailored to help you navigate your educational journey with ease.
  • A Future Tailored to You: Your goals, your aspirations, your pace. Embrace the exciting opportunities that lie ahead.

You've got the ambition and the drive. With this plan in hand, you're not just going back to school; you're moving forward in life. Let's dive in and advance your future together.

reasons.title: Higher Earning Potential
reasons.description: On average, bachelor's degree holders earn significantly more over their lifetime than those with only a high school diploma. Investing in your education can pave the way for a higher salary and improved financial stability.

reasons.title: Broader Career Opportunities
reasons.description: Many positions, especially in growing industries like technology, healthcare, and finance, often require or prefer candidates with a bachelor's degree. By completing your degree, you unlock a wider range of job prospects.

reasons.title: Personal Growth & Development
reasons.description: Beyond the career implications, college offers a holistic experience. You'll be exposed to diverse perspectives, subjects, and opportunities for personal and intellectual growth. This enriching environment can enhance your worldview, critical thinking skills, and interpersonal dynamics.

reasons.title: Networking Opportunities
reasons.description: College isn't just about what you learn in the classroom. It's also about the connections you make. Alumni networks, professors, peers, internships, and campus organizations can all provide valuable connections that might benefit your future career.

reasons.title: Flexibility & Adaptability
reasons.description: As industries evolve, those with a higher level of education tend to have an easier time adapting to changes in the job market. A bachelor's degree equips you with transferable skills that are valuable in a variety of roles.

statsSource: Association of Public and Land Grant Universities

stats.title: Higher Salary
stats.description: Typical earnings for bachelor’s degree holders are 84% higher than those whose highest degree is a high school diploma.

stats.title: More Lifetime Earnings
stats.description: College graduates on average make $1.2 million more over their lifetime.

stats.title: Less Likely to Be Unemployed
stats.description: College graduates are half as likely to be unemployed as their peers who only have a high school degree.

testimonial.text:
Something like 25 percent of entry-level jobs will be automated in the next 25 years, and so it’s likely many jobs that don’t require a bachelor’s will be eclipsed by AI or technological automation.

A college degree gives you a broad set of experiences and skills, and if or when you are replaced by a robot, or your position is diminished by new technology, with a degree you will be more nimble and better able to find another position compared to someone who hasn’t developed those skills and earned a bachelor’s degree.
testimonial.author: Ben Cater, Ph.D.
testimonial.authorTitle: Associate Dean of General Education, Point Loma Nazarene University

fundingYourDegree.title: Scholarships
fundingYourDegree.content: Scholarships are financial awards given to students based on merit, need, or specific criteria set by the provider. They don't need to be repaid.

fundingYourDegree.title: Federal Aid
fundingYourDegree.content: The U.S. Department of Education offers various financial aid options, including grants (which don't need to be repaid) and low-interest loans.

fundingYourDegree.title: Tuiton Reimbursement
fundingYourDegree.content: Check the Employee Handbook: Many companies outline their benefits, including tuition reimbursement, in the employee handbook or benefits guide.

fundingYourDegree.title: Work Study
fundingYourDegree.content: Work-study is a federal program that provides part-time jobs to students, allowing them to earn money to help pay for school. After you enroll, your college's financial aid office can provide specifics on work-study opportunities.

fundingYourDegree.title: Military
fundingYourDegree.content: Veterans Affairs education benefits help Veterans, service members, and their qualified family members with needs like paying college tuition, finding the right school or training program, and getting career counseling.

fundingYourDegree.title: Loans
fundingYourDegree.content: Loans are borrowed funds that must be repaid with interest. They can be federal or private.

importantThings.title: It Unlocks Financial Aid Opportunities
importantThings.description: The FAFSA is the gateway to a multitude of financial aid options. By completing it, you become eligible for federal grants, work-study programs, and loans. Plus, many states and colleges use FAFSA data to award their own financial aid.

importantThings.title: It’s Not Just for Freshmen
importantThings.description: Regardless of whether you're a returning adult student or a first-time undergraduate, the FAFSA is for everyone. Age isn't a barrier; the opportunities it brings are applicable to all.

importantThings.title: It’s Not Just for Federal Aid
importantThings.description: Beyond federal aid, the FAFSA can also connect you with state-specific grants and scholarships tailored for adults returning to the educational fold. Many institutions also require the FAFSA for their own scholarship and grant opportunities.

importantThings.title: It Helps You Plan
importantThings.description: Filling out the FAFSA provides you with a clearer picture of what financial assistance you qualify for. This can be instrumental in planning your educational journey without the stress of unforeseen costs.

importantThings.title: It Matters When You File
importantThings.description: The FAFSA becomes available on October 1st each year, and deadlines can vary by state and college. It's often said,'The early bird catches the worm,' and this holds true here. The sooner you file, the better your chances of receiving the maximum amount of aid available.

stats.title: In Scholarships
stats.description: Appily’s Scholarship search tool is the nation’s largest, multi-billion dollar scholarship database. After you create a free account, you can narrow down your options and apply to any scholarships that interest you within the tool.

stats.title: Receive Aid
stats.description: Approximately 85% of full-time undergraduate students who file the FAFSA receive some kind of financial aid, according to the National Center for Education Statistics (NCES).

stats.title: Of Employers Offer Educational Benefits
stats.description: The Society for Human Resource Management (SHRM) reports that while it varies from year to year, on average, between 45-55% of employers offer tuition assistance.

moreWays.title: Transfer as many credits as you can.
moreWays.description:
Many colleges accept credits from any previous college experience you have, up to a certain amount of hours. You could also pursue alternative ways of applying credits, such as:

  • ACE: If you participated in military service, workplace training programs, apprenticeships, standardized exams, or other types of experiential learning outside the college classroom, you could receive college credit recommendations or validated competencies through Learning Evaluation.
  • CLEP: These exams let you test out of introductory courses and move to more advanced courses sooner, saving time toward your degree.

Many colleges also offer their own testing programs that allow you the opportunity to test out of introductory-level courses.

moreWays.title: Look for accelerated programs.
moreWays.description: Since colleges often charge by credit hour, look for ones that offer programs with fewer total credits needed to complete your degree.

moreWays.title: Take classes one at a time.
moreWays.description: Some degrees have asynchronous options where you can take one class at a time and complete your week’s work whenever it fits your schedule. This may make it easier to pay as you go — and fit it into your busy life.

paths.title: Military
paths.content: The discipline, leadership, and strategic skills honed during military service can open doors in sectors like defense contracting, government roles, or security management. Your experience can also be highly valued in project management and logistics, where your abilities to lead and coordinate are crucial.

paths.title: Service Industry
paths.content: Your service industry experience, with its emphasis on customer relations and operational efficiency, can translate into careers in hospitality management, customer service leadership, or human resources, where your people-centric skills will continue to shine.

paths.title: Retail
paths.content: A background in retail, rich in customer service and sales experience, can pivot you toward careers in marketing, retail management, or even entrepreneurial ventures. The adaptability and commercial awareness you've gained are assets in any client-facing or business development role.

paths.title: Health Care
paths.content: Health care experience is invaluable, opening pathways to advanced clinical roles, healthcare administration, or public health advocacy. Your firsthand understanding of patient care and healthcare systems makes you a strong candidate for positions aiming to enhance healthcare delivery and policy.

paths.title: Self-Employed
paths.content: Your entrepreneurial background can propel you into leadership roles, consultancy, or business development. The initiative and innovation that come with being self-employed are sought after in the rapidly changing business landscape, tech startups, and creative industries.

paths.title: Parent
paths.content: The organizational and nurturing skills you've honed can lead to fulfilling careers in education, child development, or community services. Your talent for managing and nurturing growth is also an asset in administrative or project coordination roles.

paths.title: Other
paths.content: Diverse life experiences provide a unique lens through which you view challenges and opportunities, making you suitable for a variety of roles. Your adaptability and breadth of knowledge can be particularly advantageous in roles that require empathy, problem-solving, and a multidisciplinary approach.

topCareers.title: Top Careers in Business
topCareers.description: In the dynamic world of business, versatility and strategic acumen are paramount. The careers we've selected not only promise ample opportunities for advancement but also offer the potential for impactful roles in a variety of industries, ensuring that your investment in a business-related bachelor's degree yields substantial professional and financial rewards.

paths.title: Business Analyst
paths.description:
Job responsibilities: Analyzes organizational processes, identifies inefficiencies, and recommends solutions.

Why pursue this career: A smart choice due to the growing reliance on data-driven decision-making in business.

Related degrees: Bachelor of Business Administration (BBA) or Bachelor's in Finance

paths.title: Marketing Manager
paths.description:
Job responsibilities: Develops and oversees marketing strategies to promote products and services.

Why pursue this career: A sound career due to the constant need for businesses to differentiate and compete.

Related degrees: Bachelor's in Marketing or Bachelor's in Business Administration

paths.title: Financial Analyst
paths.description:
Job responsibilities: Evaluates investment opportunities and provides guidance to businesses or individuals.

Why pursue this career: A wise choice given the critical role of financial planning in both corporate and personal finance.

Related degrees: Bachelor's in Finance or Bachelor's in Economics

paths.title: Human Resources Manager
paths.description:
Job responsibilities: Oversees employee relations, recruitment, and compliance with labor laws.

Why pursue this career: A stable choice because of the enduring necessity of managing an organization's workforce.

Related degrees: Bachelor's in Human Resources or Bachelor's in Business Administration

paths.title: Supply Chain Manager
paths.description:
Job responsibilities: Manages the entire lifecycle of a product, from sourcing to delivery.

Why pursue this career: A prudent choice given the increasing complexity and globalization of supply chains.

Related degrees: Bachelor's in Supply Chain Management or Bachelor's in Business Administration

degreeTabs.title: What degree do I need for a career in information technology and analytics?
degreeTabs.description: Thriving in the dynamic fields of technology and data analysis requires a solid educational foundation. While a bachelor's degree is a starting point, advancing your education to a master's level can significantly enhance your skills and unlock a wealth of opportunities.

degrees.title: Management of Information Systems
degrees.content:
A degree in Management of Information Systems combines business knowledge with expertise in managing information technology and data.

Example degrees: Master of Science in Management Information Systems (MS-MIS), Master of Business Administration (MBA) with a concentration in Information Systems Management

degrees.title: Information Technology
degrees.content:
A degree in Information Technology covers various aspects of technology management and infrastructure.

Example degrees: Master of Information Technology (MIT), Master of Science in Information Technology (MSIT), Master of Business Administration (MBA) with a specialization in Information Technology

degrees.title: Business Analytics
degrees.content:
A degree in Business Analytics focuses on using data analysis and statistics to inform business decision-making.

Example degrees: Master of Science in Business Analytics (MSBA), Master of Business Administration (MBA) with a focus on Business Analytics

degrees.title: Business Statistics
degrees.content:
A degree in Business Statistics emphasizes analyzing and interpreting data to solve business problems.

Example degrees: Master of Science in Business Statistics, Master of Business Administration (MBA) with a concentration in Business Statistics

degrees.title: System Administrator
degrees.content:
A degree in System Administration equips individuals with skills to manage and maintain computer systems and networks.

Example degrees: Master of Science in System Administration, Master of Information Technology with a specialization in System Administration

degrees.title: Financial Analytics
degrees.content:
A degree in Financial Analytics focuses on using data analysis to inform financial decision-making.

Example degrees: Master of Financial Analytics, Master of Business Administration (MBA) with a concentration in Financial Analytics

textWithImage.content:
Do I need a Master’s or an MBA?

You can amplify your tech prowess with an MBA in Information Technology that merges business strategy with tech innovation, enhancing your analytical and managerial skills.

Alternatively, a Master's in Data Analytics dives deep into harnessing data insights for business decisions. Or a Master's in Management of Information Systems gets into the finer details of managing information technology and data.

While both paths revolve around technology, the MBA offers a broader spectrum of business knowledge, making it the prime choice for The Computer Whiz envisioning a dynamic role in bridging tech and business realms.
